Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support to attend The 16th International Heat Transfer Conference (Beijing, China, August 10-15, 2018)

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The International Heat Transfer Conference has a long and rich history, which dates back to the International Discussion on Heat Transfer held in London and Atlantic City in 1951. In 1966, with the third conference held in Chicago, the International Heat Transfer Conference started a four-year cycle, having been organized already in 16 different cities of 9 countries. As the world's premier thermal transport processes conferences, researchers, engineers and scientists from all over the world get together to exchange knowledge and experience and introduce novel interdisciplinary research ideas. The International Heat Transfer Conference continues the increasingly important mission of fostering international cooperation and the exchange of ideas among scientists and engineers in the heat and mass transfer research community, together with engaging underrepresented minorities in its activities.

The International Heat Transfer Conference is the largest worldwide forum on heat transfer and thermal science and engineering. The organization is devoted to meeting the scientific and social challenges of thermal energy usage, environmental sustainability, materials processing, and bioscience. The mission of International Heat Transfer Conference has become more important with the rapid development of human society. The International Heat Transfer Conference will be held in Beijing, China, August 10-15, 2018. It is under the auspices of the Assembly for International Heat Transfer Conferences, an institution founded in 1966, with the principal goal of creating and sustaining a worldwide forum for heat transfer specialists to present research results, discuss the state of the art techniques in heat transfer areas, and identify the future direction and priorities in the various domains of thermal science and engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Heat Transfer Conference (IHTC) is the largest worldwide forum on heat transfer (HT) and thermal science and engineering (TSE).  The organization is devoted to meeting the scientific and social challenges of thermal energy usage, environmental sustainability, materials processing, and bioscience. The IHTC 16 continued the increasingly important mission of fostering international cooperation and the exchange of ideas among scientists and engineers in the heat and mass transfer research community.

The IHTC 16 was successfully held in Beijing, China, August 10-15, 2018. It included 3 plenary lectures, 28 keynote lectures, 4 panel sessions, 40 general sessions, nearly 1000 papers from more than 40 countries and regions and more than 1400 participants. More than 1800 abstracts were initially submitted to the conference which were reviewed by the members of the Assembly of International Heat Transfer Conferences (AIHTC). The full-length paper were then reviewed by peer reviewers assigned by the members of AIHTC. Those papers covered a various aspects in heat transfer, thermal transport processes as well as many new heat and mass transport research areas.

This NSF travel fund was used to provide travel support for 10 U.S. citizens or permanent residents to participate in the IHTC 16 conference, with preference given to underrepresented minority applicants. The population for the awardees included women and other underrepresented graduate students, post-doctoral fellows, non-tenured faculty or recently tenured faculty with limited research funding. Minority scientists or engineers from industries including national laboratories in their early career and working in the field of heat transfer were also be included. 

The travel support provided a unique opportunity for underrepresented minorites in heat transfer to gain exposure to the broader heat transfer community. All the travel grant receipent students and post-doctoral fellows presented papers and attended  programs at the conference.  Exposure to cutting-edge research will impact their future studies and career path. For non-tenured or young tenured faculties, the experience will enable them to form collaborations with respected peers and further a vision of leadership in the heat transfer community.

Total NSF funding ($18,000) were requested to provide travel support for 12 U.S. citizens or permanent residents to participate in the IHTC 16 conference, with preference given to underrepresented minority applicants. $1500 for each awardee.

Based on IHTC 16 participant?s ratio, this proposal expect to allocate 20% of the travel fund to students and 80% to junior and underrepresented minority researchers in heat transfer area. Preference will be given to those whose home institute would cost-share the expenses. 

Announcement of this travel support information were made available to IHTC 16 participant, the Secretary General, Dr. David M. Christopher, provided great support on it. PI has served in ASME Computational Heat Transfer Committee since 2007, the IHTC 16 travel support information was also sent to ASME Heat Transfer Division before the conference.

The Applicants submitted their CV, along with the draft paper acceptance letter to PI for consideration.

Originally 12 participants were identified. 10 out of the 12 made the trip to China to attend the conference, and 2 of the 12 cannot attend the conference as planned. Travel reimbursement were made to all of the 10 awardees after the conference. The total reimbursement amount is $14,976.98. Details are shown in the table 1.
